questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.
You are deploying Direct Routing with media bypass.
You need to define a Session Border Controller (SBC) in Teams.
How should you complete the command? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Correct answer is B:
If a device receives a "No SIP Options" message, it means that the options message was not received or that the receiving device was unable to process the message. This can be caused by a variety of issues, such as network congestion, firewall or network security configurations, or issues with the SIP devices themselves.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct
The answer is C. TCP port used by Microsoft is 5061. The destination port is configurable, but it is never port 443. So answer B is not correct.

Selected Answer: B
Having just that single screenshot it is hard to say anything about the certificate.
Option B - firewall outbound rule to 443 MS Teams Service - could affect SIP Options messages sent from SBC.

choices.A: The tenant is missing a vanity domain of voice.contoso.com.
choices.B: The firewall blocks outbound traffic on port 443 to Microsoft Teams.
choices.D: Media bypass is disabled on the SBC.
choices.C: The certificate does not match the FQDN of the SBC.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.
You are deploying Direct Routing.
All users have a SIP URI in the format of user@contoso.com. The Session Border Controller (SBC) is named sbc.voice.contoso.com.
When troubleshooting errors on the SBC, you receive the warning shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

What is a possible cause of the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Should be B in my view.

Selected Answer: B
The installed root or intermediate certificate isn't part of the SBC certificate chain issuer. When the SBC starts the three-way handshake during the authentication process, the Teams service won't be able to validate the certificate chain on the SBC and will reset the connection. The SBC may be able to authenticate again as soon as the public Root certificate is loaded again on the service cache or the certificate chain is fixed on the SBC. Make sure that the intermediate and root certificate installed on the SBC are correct.

Selected Answer: B
For me it is B

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/troubleshoot/phone-system/direct-routing/sip-options-tls-certificate-issues

Selected Answer: B
I say it's B:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/troubleshoot/phone-system/direct-routing/sip-options-tls-certificate-issues#sip-options-issues

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/troubleshoot/phone-system/direct-routing/sip-options-tls-certificate-issues

The SBC is marked as inactive in the Microsoft Teams admin center.
So I think C is correct.
B is the right answere, as TLS is inactive
C is not right. TLS would come up with or without SIP Options. I'm thinking B - pointing to a cert issue.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.
You are deploying Direct Routing by using a certified Session Border Controller (SBC). The FQDN of the SBC is sbc1.contoso.com. You are signaling port 5067.
You cannot place calls and receive an error message in the Microsoft Teams admin center as shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

What is a possible cause of the issue?

choices.D: The failover timer is set to 0 seconds.
choices.A: Calling plan licenses are not assigned to users.
choices.B: The Baltimore root certificate is missing on the SBC.

questions.answer_description:
Step 1: From Microsoft 365 admin center, add and validate the contoso.com domain
Add a base domain to the tenant and verify it.
1. In the Microsoft 365 admin center, go to Setup > Domains > Add domain.
2. In the Enter a domain you own box, type the FQDN of the base domain. In the following example, the base domain is customers.adatum.biz.
3. Click Next.
4. If you add an FQDN that has not been verified before, you'll need to go through the process of verification.
5. Etc.
Step 2: From Microsoft 365 admin center, add a licensed user that has a UPN to the contoso.com domain.
Activate the domain name.
After you have registered a domain name, you need to activate it by adding at least one user with a Phone System license and assigning a SIP address with the
FQDN portion of the SIP address matching the created base domain.
Step 3: From Microsoft 365 admin center, add the SBC as sbc1.contoso.com
Add the FQDNs for the SBC. In this case sbc1.contoso.com.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/direct-routing-sbc-multiple-tenants
questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.
When you attempt to deploy a Session Border Controller (SBC) named sbc1.contoso.com, you receive the following error message: "We can't use the
"SBC1.contoso.com" domain as it hasn't been set up in the organization. Try again. If you continue to have problems, contact Microsoft customer support."
You need to add the SBC to the tenant.
Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
From my point of view: ( The answer is correct)
1.- From the Microsoft 365 admin center, add and validate the contoso.com domain.
2.- From the Microsoft 365 admin center, add a licensed user that has a UPN to 
the contoso.como domain ( If we don't do this, we aren't enable to create the SBC fqdn)
3.- From the Microsoft Teams admin center add the SBC as SBC sbc1.contoso.com

1. From the Microsoft 365 admin center, add and validate the contoso.com domain.
 2. From the Microsoft Teams admin center, enable external access for the contoso.com domain.
 3. From the Microsoft Teams admin center add the SBC as SBS as sbc1.contoso.com.

comments.content: You need to add a user on the new domain, otherwise it wont validate.

questions.question_text:
Your company has offices in Paris and London.
You are migrating from an on-premises PBX telephony solution to a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment that uses Direct Routing. You plan to use the existing telephony carrier. The new solution will provide telephony services to users in both offices.
You need to recommend a solution that is the most resistant to possible failures. The solution must ensure that calls are routed through each user s respective office.
Which two actions should you include in the recommendation? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

comments.content: because is very unlikely, even same carrier (for both lcation) in case of circuit failure, will failover calls to other site, and route properly inbound/outbound

choices.C: Configure voice routing policies for each office.
choices.D: Configure a single voice routing policy for all users.
choices.A: Deploy one Session Border Controller (SBC) to each office. Configure the SBCs as a high-availability pair.
choices.B: Deploy a highly available Session Border Controller (SBC) pair to each office.

questions.answer_description:
B: Microsoft only supports the certified SBCs to pair with Direct Routing.
SBCs in each site must be paired with Direct Routing to provide dial tone and PSTN calling capabilities by using your own trunks.
C: The solution must ensure that calls are routed through each user s respective office.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/onboarding-checklist-configure-direct-routing-in-microsoft-teams https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/direct-routing-voice-routing
